title: 108_s2420
content: The "SCHIP Expansion Act of 2004" allows all uninsured children to be eligible for SCHIP. The Social Security Act is amended to include a child who is uninsured for SCHIP eligibility. The Social Security Act is amended to include a child who is uninsured for SCHIP eligibility by making certain changes to Section 2110(b)(3). The Social Security Act is amended to include a child who is uninsured for SCHIP eligibility by making changes to Section 2110(b)(3), including adjustments to the rules for certain non federally funded coverage and prohibiting the exclusion of children with access to high-cost coverage. A State cannot exclude a child from being considered a targeted vulnerable child with access to health coverage if the total annual cost exceeds 5 percent of the family's income. The Social Security Act is amended to ensure insurance coverage for vulnerable children in families where the cost does not exceed 5 percent of the family's income. The Social Security Act is amended to provide insurance coverage for vulnerable children, particularly those in families with income exceeding 200 percent of the poverty line, effective October 1, 2004. SEC. 3. Increase in federal financial participation under SCHIP and Medicaid for states with simplified enrollment and renewal procedures for children. Increase in federal financial participation under SCHIP and Medicaid for states with simplified enrollment and renewal procedures for children, including the nonapplication of limitations on expenditures for certain items. The limitation on expenditures for certain items does not apply if outreach strategies are carried out for children under title XIX, and there is an enhanced FMAP for states with simplified enrollment and renewal procedures for children under SCHIP and Medicaid. The limitation on expenditures does not apply if outreach strategies are carried out for children under title XIX, and the enhanced FMAP for a State shall be increased by 5 percentage points for such expenditures. The State can increase the enhanced FMAP by 5 percentage points for outreach strategies related to presumptive eligibility for children under title XIX. The State provides presumptive eligibility for children under this title and title XIX, with eligibility not redetermined more than once a year. The State does not redetermine eligibility more than once a year for children under this title or title XIX, and does not apply an asset test for eligibility. Automatic renewal of children's eligibility is provided. The State allows for passive renewal of children's eligibility for assistance under this title and title XIX if no changes are reported, verified through State databases. Changes to family income or relevant circumstances are subject to verification from State databases. Medicaid section 1902(l) of the Social Security Act is amended to include new provisions regarding eligibility. The text chunk introduces amendments to the Social Security Act regarding Medicaid eligibility for individuals under 19 years of age. It specifies that the Federal medical assistance percentage will be equal to the enhanced FMAP for outreach strategies targeting this demographic. For individuals under 19 years of age eligible for medical assistance, the Federal medical assistance percentage is based on enhanced FMAP and outreach strategies must align with those for children under title XXI, including presumptive eligibility and 12-month continuous eligibility. The State provides 12-month continuous eligibility without asset tests for individuals under title XXI, ensuring automatic renewal of assistance eligibility. The State ensures automatic renewal of assistance eligibility for individuals under title XXI, with passive renewal if no changes are reported. Amendments are made to the Social Security Act. Amendments to the Social Security Act include changing the first sentence of section 1905(b) to include sections 1902(l)(5) and 1933(d). The effective date for these amendments is October 1, 2004. Elimination of SCHIP DIP and increase in funding. The Social Security Act is amended to increase funding for certain paragraphs, with changes in dollar amounts. The effective date for these amendments is October 1, 2004. SEC. 5. LIMITATION ON PAYMENTS TO STATES WITH ENROLLMENT CAPS BUT UNUSED ALLOTMENTS. Limitation on Payments to States with Enrollment Caps: Payment will not be made to a State under this section if the State has an enrollment freeze, cap, or waiting list for child health assistance applications and has not exhausted available allotments. The State will not receive payment under this section if it delays or does not consider child health assistance applications, has a waiting list, and has not used all available allotments. The amendments made by this section allow states to establish open enrollment periods for child health assistance applications, effective October 1, 2004. Section 2107(e)(1) of the Social Security Act is amended to include requirements for managed care under SCHIP, effective October 1, 2004.
